title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Understand how and when to use sets, tuples, and dictionaries
Explain mutability vs. immutability and implications for hashing
Apply tuple unpacking safely and predictably

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
What I focused on

Python core data structures: sets, tuples, dictionaries
Mutability vs. immutability and how it relates to hashability
Tuple packing/unpacking patterns and pitfalls

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Notes / Bits I picked up

Empty set literal is set(), not {} (that’s an empty dict).
Sets are unordered, unique collections; you cannot index into a set.
Tuples are immutable; beware stray trailing commas creating tuples unexpectedly.
Tuple unpacking requires counts to match; use _ for values you do not need.
Dictionaries are keyed mappings; use in to check key existence.
Hashable typically implies immutable; lists/dicts/sets are unhashable, tuples/ints/str are hashable.

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Resources

Frontend Masters — Practical Guide to Python (full course): https://frontendmasters.com/courses/practical-python/

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Demos / Experiments

Quick REPL exercises for constructing sets from lists, tuple unpacking, and dict updates.

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text: Finished the Frontend Masters Practical Guide to Python lesson on Sets, Tuples, & Dictionaries (course link).

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Understand how and when to use sets, tuples, and dictionaries
Explain mutability vs. immutability and implications for hashing
Apply tuple unpacking safely and predictably

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Key notes

Empty set literal is set(), not {} (that’s an empty dict).
Sets are unordered, unique collections; you cannot index into a set.
Tuples are immutable; beware stray trailing commas creating tuples unexpectedly.
Tuple unpacking requires counts to match; use _ for values you do not need.
Dictionaries are keyed mappings; use in to check key existence.
Hashable typically implies immutable; lists/dicts/sets are unhashable, tuples/ints/str are hashable.

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Exercises

Practice in REPL: construct sets from lists, perform tuple unpacking, and update dicts.

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Readiness checklist

Can create and manipulate sets, and explain why they are unordered
Can define tuples and avoid accidental tuple creation via trailing commas
Can unpack tuples defensively and handle mismatched lengths
Can use dictionaries idiomatically (membership checks, updates)

title: Week of Oct 13, 2025
text:
Examples

Numbers and booleans

a = 12
b = 3.5
total = a + b
is_equal = (a == 2)
truthy = True and (1 < 2)
falsy = False or (2 > 5)
not_val = not False

print(a, type(a))
print(b, type(b))
print(total)
print(is_equal, truthy, falsy, not_val)

12 <class 'int'>
3.5 <class 'float'>
15.5
False True False True




Strings and f-strings

name = "Charlotte"
lang = "Python"
msg = f"Hi {name}, welcome to {lang}!"

print(name.upper())
print(len(name))
print("thon" in lang)
print(msg)

CHARLOTTE
9
True
Hi Charlotte, welcome to Python!




Lists

nums = [1, 2, 3]
nums.append(4)
sliced = nums[1:3]
doubled = [x * 2 for x in nums]

print(nums)
print(sliced)
print(doubled)

[1, 2, 3, 4]
[2, 3]
[2, 4, 6, 8]




Tuples

t = (1, "a", True)
single = (42,)
packed = 1, 2  # tuple without parentheses
x, y = (10, 20)  # unpacking

print(t)
print(single)
print(packed)
print(x, y)

# t[0] = 99  # TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment

(1, 'a', True)
(42,)
(1, 2)
10 20




Dictionaries

user = {"name": "Charlotte", "role": "AI Engineer"}
user["city"] = "Ipswich"

print(user["name"])       # indexing by key
print("role" in user)      # membership check on keys
print(user)

Charlotte
True
{'name': 'Charlotte', 'role': 'AI Engineer', 'city': 'Ipswich'}




Sets

names = ["alice", "bob", "alice"]
s = set(names)
s.add("carol")

print(s)
print("alice" in s)

{'alice', 'bob', 'carol'}
True




Hash function and hashability

print(hash(("a", 1)))  # tuples are hashable if their items are hashable
print(hash("abc"))

# hash([1, 2])   # TypeError: unhashable type: 'list'
# hash({"k": 1}) # TypeError: unhashable type: 'dict'

7782685935025665217
6692948680666049919




Logic: and / or / in

print(True and False)
print(True or False)
print(False or 0)
print(0 or "fallback")
print("x" and "y")      # returns last truthy operand
print("py" in "python")  # substring membership

False
True
0
fallback
y
True




Functions

def my_function(x=4):
   return x + 2

my_function()

6



def my_other_function(x):
   return x * 2

my_other_function(21312)

42624



def another_cat(x, y, z=12):
   return z + (x + y)

another_cat(1, 2)

15




Conditionals

def my_dogs(x, one, two):
    if x == 2:
        return f"my doggos are {one} and {two}"
    elif x > 2:
        return "Soon! soon we will have them all!"
    else: 
        return "Got no doggos"

my_dogs(1, "Annie", "Anubis")

'Got no doggos'



def fizzbuzz(number):
    if (number % 3 == 0) and (number % 5 == 0):
        print("fizz")
    else: print("buzz")

fizzbuzz(15)
fizzbuzz(5)

fizz
buzz




Loops

family = ["Annie", "Anubis", "Alex", "Charlotte"]

for family_member in family:
    print(f"My name is {family_member}!")

print(f"outside of the loop {family_member}")

list(enumerate(family))

My name is Annie!
My name is Anubis!
My name is Alex!
My name is Charlotte!
outside of the loop Charlotte


[(0, 'Annie'), (1, 'Anubis'), (2, 'Alex'), (3, 'Charlotte')]


enumerate returns list of tuples , first item index, second item the value

colours = ["Red", "Yellow", "Pink", "Green", "Orange", "Purple", "Blue"]

for index, colour in enumerate(colours):
    print(f"this is the greatest colour {colour} number {index}")

this is the greatest colour Red number 0
this is the greatest colour Yellow number 1
this is the greatest colour Pink number 2
this is the greatest colour Green number 3
this is the greatest colour Orange number 4
this is the greatest colour Purple number 5
this is the greatest colour Blue number 6



concepts_to_learn = {
    "Python": "Language",
    "TensorFlow": "Execution Env",
    "Pytorch": "differnt exectuion place",
    "Deep Learning": "Neural networks and that"
}

for foo in concepts_to_learn:
    print(foo)

Python
TensorFlow
Pytorch
Deep Learning



concepts_to_learn.items()

dict_items([('Python', 'Language'), ('TensorFlow', 'Execution Env'), ('Pytorch', 'differnt exectuion place'), ('Deep Learning', 'Neural networks and that')])



for key, value in concepts_to_learn.items():
    print(key) 
    print("----")
    print(value)

Python
----
Language
TensorFlow
----
Execution Env
Pytorch
----
differnt exectuion place
Deep Learning
----
Neural networks and that



x = 0
while x < 5:
    print(x)
    x += 1

0
1
2
3
4



names = ["Lisa", "Bob", "Jeremy", "Django", "Mario"]

def return_target(target="Jeremy"):
    for name in names:
        print(name)
        if name == target:
            print(f"we found {target}!")
            return name



List comprehensions

names = ["Lisa", "Bob", "Jeremy", "Django", "Mario"]
my_list = []

for name in names:
    my_list.append(len(name))

print("First way: ", my_list)

print("Shorter way:", [len(name) for name in names])

First way:  [4, 3, 6, 6, 5]
Shorter way: [4, 3, 6, 6, 5]



nums = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

[num * 2 for num in nums] 

[0, 2, 4, 6, 8]




Slicing

my_cake = "Hey this is a big cake!"
my_cake[14:22]

my_cake[:18]
my_cake[19:]
my_cake[-1]

'!'




files - reading, writing, appending, and JSON
Below are executable examples that will run in this page’s kernel. They demonstrate different open() modes and working with a small JSON file stored alongside this page at learning-journey/data/example.json.

# Write: creates or truncates file
with open("my_file.txt", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write("first line\n")
    f.write("second line\n")

# Append: adds to end of file
with open("my_file.txt", "a", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write("appended line\n")

# Read entire file
with open("my_file.txt", "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    contents = f.read()
contents

'first line\nsecond line\nappended line\n'



# Read line-by-line
with open("my_file.txt", "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    for line in f:
        print(line.rstrip())

first line
second line
appended line



# Explicit open/close (less preferred vs. context manager)
f = open("my_file.txt", "r", encoding="utf-8")
try:
    print(f.readline().rstrip())
finally:
    f.close()

first line



# pathlib usage
from pathlib import Path

path = Path("my_file.txt")
path.write_text("overwritten via pathlib\n", encoding="utf-8")
print(path.read_text(encoding="utf-8"))

overwritten via pathlib





Classes

class Car:
    runs = True

    def start(self):
        if self.runs:
            print("The car starts.")
        else:
            print("The car is broken.")

my_car = Car()
my_car.start()
my_car.runs = False
my_car.start()

my_other_car = Car()
my_other_car.start()

The car starts.
The car is broken.
The car starts.




isinstance

print(isinstance(my_car, Car))
print(isinstance(my_car, str))
print(isinstance("Hallo there", str))
print(isinstance(12, int))

True
False
True
True




initializing classes

class Supersupercar:
    runs = True
    def __init__(self, make, model, year):
        self.make = make
        self.model = model
        self.year = year

    def start(self):
        if self.runs:
            print(f"The {self.make} {self.model} {self.year} starts.")
        else:
            print(f"The {self.make} {self.model} {self.year} is broken.")

my_car = Supersupercar("Toyota", "Corolla", 2020)
my_car.start()

my_better_car = Supersupercar("Mustang", "GT", 2025)
my_better_car.start()

The Toyota Corolla 2020 starts.
The Mustang GT 2025 starts.





Mustang GT




inheritance

class Mustang(Supersupercar):
    def __init__(self, make, model, year, color):
        super().__init__(make, model, year)
        self.color = color

my_jaguar = Mustang("Jaguar", "2027", 2027, "Green")
my_jaguar.start()

The Jaguar 2027 2027 starts.





Jaguar 2027




Exceptions

try:
    print(10 / 0)
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("You can't divide by zero!")

try:
    print(10 / 2)
except ValueError:
    print("You can divide by two!")

You can't divide by zero!
5.0
